entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French frut, fruit, from Latin fructus fruit, use, from frui to enjoy, have the use of brook

def.dt: :a product of plant growth (as grain, vegetables, or cotton) the fruits of the field
:the usually edible reproductive body of a seed plant
:one having a sweet pulp associated with the seed the fruit of the tree
:a succulent plant part (as the petioles of a rhubarb plant) used chiefly in a dessert or sweet course
:a dish, quantity, or diet of fruits live on fruit
:a product of fertilization in a plant with its modified envelopes or appendages
:the ripened ovary of a seed plant and its contents
:the flavor or aroma of fresh fruit in mature wine
:offspring progeny
:the state of bearing fruit a tree in fruit
:the effect or consequence of an action or operation :product result the fruits of our labor
:a male homosexual
:to bear fruit
:to cause to bear fruit

:any of a family (Pteropodidae of the suborder Megachiroptera) of often large tropical and subtropical Old World bats that feed on ripe fruit, pollen, and nectar and that usually use visual navigation rather than echolocation called also flying fox
:any of various small dipteran flies (as a drosophila) whose larvae feed on fruit or decaying vegetable matter
:slot machine 2
:fructose 2
:a fruit (as the apple) of which a conspicuous part consists of tissue other than that of the ripened ovary
:a fruit (as a berry, drupe, or pome) consisting largely of soft succulent tissue

entry.et: from the forbidden fruit of the Garden of Eden in Genesis 3:2–19

def.dt: :an immoral or illegal pleasure
:a small widely distributed yellowish-brown dipteran fly (Ceratitis capitata) with a banded abdomen whose larva lives and feeds in ripening fruit called also medfly
